name__text: Melbourne Free Walking Tour
description__text: Join our tour guides for a walk through Australia?s culture capital and learn what makes this city great and so much more.   Our guides believe that walking tours should be available to everyone ? regardless of your budget. This free tour of Melbourne to provide an excellent introduction to the city, and our guides accept tips at the end of the tour. Explore Melbourne with a local who can share the history of the city as well as point out things to do after your walking tour is done. Walks 101 tour guides want to show you the real Melbourne ? the city we know and love. The tour concludes near the Old Melbourne Gaol, where you learn about Australia?s most infamous bush ranger. After your tour is finished, your guide brings the group to a classic Australian pub where you can experience traditional Aussie food.   FAQs ÿ Is it really free? Absolutely. Our guides will never pressure you to give money at the end. That said, you will be given an opportunity to pay your guide what you felt the tour was worth. Our guides are not volunteers ? they make their living from giving free walking tours. As a result, our guides areÿvery motivated to give you the best tour you've ever experienced. What are my transportation/parking options for getting to and from the event? We strongly recommend public transportation, as city parking spaces are limited, and all nearby spaces have a time limit that is shorter than our tour. Do I have to bring my printed ticket to the event? Nope ? just have it ready on your phone.ÿ What if I'm running late? Each of our tours is custom tailored to the group, the guide, and the weather. As a result, it can be very difficult to locate the guide ? especially because our guides are instructed to silence their phones during the tour. Please arrive on time, and if you are late, don't worry ? we run multiple tours every day ? just catch the next one! Where will the tour end? Our tour concludes at Captain Melville pub, where our guests get an exclusive discount if they order a meal.
summary: Join our tour guides for a walk through Australia?s culture capital and learn what makes this city great and so much more.   Our guides be

name__text: Seeing Eye Dogs Puppy Carer Info Session: Kensington June 15
description__text: Could you care for a future Seeing Eye Dog in 2019? Be sure you attend and get all the info you need.The puppy caring program requires volunteers to care for a puppy in their home from the age of 8 weeks, until they are approximately 12-15 months of age.Full time carers are needed however if a shorter time is more suitable and you can commit to a minimum of 6 months, this may be the option for you.If you become a puppy carer, you will be given support and guidance from the Seeing Eye Dogs team who will spend time with you to assess your needs to determine the best caring option to suit your lifestyle.ÿAt our information evening you will find out how rewarding it is to become a puppy carer.ÿHear personal accounts from people who are blind or have low vision, and how their Seeing Eye Dog has improved their independence.Discover how you can help make a difference.Register your interest to attend a Puppy & Foster Carer Information session atÿhttp://bit.ly/sedpuppycarersÿIf you have any questions, please email: SEDvolunteer@visionaustralia.org
summary: Could you care for a future Seeing Eye Dog in 2019? Be sure you attend and get all the info you need.The puppy caring program requires volun

A Criminology information session will follow directly after the Bachelor of Arts information session from 6:00-6.30pm. name__text: ACS Victoria CoderDojo (Southbank)
description__text: CoderDojo sessions are set up and run by technically skilled volunteers with relevant teaching and computer programming experience. The sessions are designed to be informal and fun for children where they are encouraged to help and teach one another, aiding them to become confident in learning their new computer skills.The ACS Southbank sessions for Term 2 of 2019 will run fortnightly from 4.30-6.00pm starting Thursday 2 May at the ACS Victoria office. There are only 20 spots available, so advance bookings are required. It is advised that all attendeesÿmust bring along a laptop, tablet or smart phone with Wi-Fi accessÿand that parents must be present for the entire session. It is also advised that families are informed prior that photographs or video footage may be taken during these sessions for promotional purposes. If you would like to learn more about the CoderDojo program, you can find out more information on the CoderDojo website -ÿhttps://coderdojo.com/start-a-dojo/ For more information please contactÿacsvic@acs.org.au
summary: CoderDojo sessions are set up and run by technically skilled volunteers with relevant teaching and computer programming experience. The sess

name__text: Information Session: Learning about BPD for Families & Friends
description__text: *Please note thisÿinformation sessionÿis designed for carers ie families and friends of people with Borderline Personality Disorderÿ(BPD) - not workersÿ This evening information session for families, friends and significant others who support someone withÿ(or a likely diagnosis of BPD)ÿwill assist participants to develop an understanding of BPD and how to access information around supports and resources in a supportive, safe environment amongst other carers.ÿ NB - This is a general information session.ÿ For more in depth educational and practical approaches to learning new skills and ways to support your family/friend with BPD you may wish to consider our full day Workshop: Learning more about BPD. All attendees will be invited to participate in a study to evaluate the effectiveness of the workshops. This will involve answering some questions about your knowledge of BPD and the impact of your caring role on your own well-being. Further information about this will be sent to prior to the workshop. Research participation is entirely voluntary. However information gained will be helpful for Spectrum to potentially influence health management, clinical practice and policy to adapt personality disorder services to address the specific needs of the community. Presenters Rita Brownÿis the Carer Consultant for Spectrum and provides a lived experience of supporting/caring for someone with BPD at a number of Spectrum?s workshops. Rita is a volunteer and board member of the Australian BPD Foundation and a co-facilitator of the Mind Australia BPD Family and Carer Support Group. Rita will be supported byÿa senior Spectrum clinician. Who should register?ÿÿFamily and friends of people withÿ(or a likely diagnosis of)ÿborderline personality disorder. Cost:ÿFree Tea and coffeeÿwill be provided.ÿ Public Transport:ÿEasily accessible via public transport.ÿ Limited streetÿparking.ÿ Please take note of any Permit Parking applicable after 5pm. General enquiries:ÿSpectrum (03) 8833 3050 or email spectrumtraining@easternhealth.org.au NB Spectrum provides training to clinicians and workers through it's Professional Development Team.ÿ To download a copy of available training clickÿhere
summary: *Please note thisÿinformation sessionÿis designed for carers ie families and friends of people with Borderline Personality Disorderÿ(BPD) -

name__text: Melbourne Peer Support Network Meeting - June 2019
description__text: PARTICIPANT FEEDBACK "... tremendous opportunity to get to know others working in same field ..." Meaningful Ageing Australia is pleased to invite you to our Melbourne Peer Support Network Meeting hosted by Villa Maria Catholic Homes. This is an opportunity to gather with others who have spiritual care responsibilities: you may be a specialist spiritual or pastoral carer, or in another role such as team leader, nurse, activities, volunteer coordinator or case manager. In these meetings you will have the opportunity to enrich your work with older people by sharing ideas about best practice,ÿstories of meaningful connections, discuss the various challenges of the role and ways to meet these challenges, and engage with a sense of shared vision for spiritual care.ÿÿ This event is for staff working with Meaningful Ageing Australia member organisations only. If you are unsure about whether your organisation is currently a member, please visit ourÿwebsite. Members can invite non-members as a guest. Please forward this invitation to your colleagues. If you would like to set up one of our Peer Support Networks in your local area, please get in touch.
summary: PARTICIPANT FEEDBACK "... tremendous opportunity to get to know others working in same field ..." Meaningful Ageing Australia is pleased to

name__text: Your Time Starts Now: Melbourne, VIC
description__text: Register now for Teach For Australia's Information Session. In order to receive all details, please remember to register.ÿ This is your chance to find out more about the work that we do, how you could benefit from this incredible opportunity, and how to put your best foot forward when submitting your Leadership Development Program application. WHY? Because educational inequity is one of the most persistent and corrosive social problems that our country faces. It?s unfair and unacceptable, but you can help us tackle it. Teach For Australia Associates don't start out as teachers. We attract both graduates and professionals who represent a range of academic disciplines and career aspirations. HOW DOES IT WORK?  Over two challenging and unbelievably rewarding years, you will completeÿour award-winning Leadership Development Program (Top 100 Graduate Employers). While you teachÿat one of our partner secondary schools you will receive full salary and benefits. By the end of the program, you will have earned a nationally accredited Master of Teaching (Professional Practice) degree on assisted-scholarship.  A LITTLE ABOUT YOU... Are you looking for a challenge and a way to give back?Is a career that will open up infinite options for your future what you seek?Did you experience inequality through personal experience or volunteer work?Have you always wanted to be a teacher? Everyone has a stake in tackling the systemic inequities of our education system. Attend this information session to find out more, to ask your questions and to begin your journey. Your time starts now.ÿ Find out more: www.teachforaustralia.org Is waitingÿtoo much to bear? Please email apply@teachforaustralia.org with any questions or to arrange a time to speak with one of our recruitment team.
summary: Register now for Teach For Australia's Information Session. In order to receive all details, please remember to register.ÿ This is your chan

name__text: Duldig Studio Open Sunday
description__text: Visit us on the second Sunday of every monthÿfor a unique experience and insight into the lives and works of sculptor Karl Duldig (1902-1986) and his artist-inventor wife, Slawa Horowitz-Duldig (c1902-1975).ÿEntry is by gold coin donation and a guided tour will take place at 2pm by an experienced volunteer guide. Duldig Studio museum + sculpture garden, is a public house museum, art gallery and sculpture garden. It is the former home and studio of Karl Duldig and Slawa Horowitz-Duldig. View the sculptures, drawings, paintings and decorative arts that tell the story of their creative lives in Vienna, Singapore and Melbourne. The story of Karl and Slawa is one of survival and resilience. The collection illustrates pre-war European art and culture as well as celebrating the contribution refugees and migrants have made to Australia?s cultural, political and social development. A changing exhibition program in a dedicated gallery space and diverse cultural events and educational initiatives connect adults and children of all ages ? inspiring creative journeys.  CURRENT EXHIBITION: SLAWA: MODERNIST ART & DESIGNArt, innovation and reinvention - discover the world of a Viennese modernist in MelbourneAn exhibition by the Austrian-Australian artist, Slawa Horowitz-Duldig (1901-1975). The exhibition presents her early graphic works and sculptures and gives insight into Viennese art of the early modernist period. Follow SLAWA's story ? told through her drawings, sculptures, fashion and furniture design, and her ingenious invention of the folding umbrella.  Image credit: Photograph by Dayne Edward
summary: Visit us on the second Sunday of every monthÿfor a unique experience and insight into the lives and works of sculptor Karl Duldig (1902-1986

name__text: Stagwatch
description__text: La Trobe Wildlife Sanctuary - Citizen Science Event Come and help monitor arboreal mammals, birds and bats that utilise the nest boxes and natural tree hollows throughout the La Trobe Wildlife Sanctuary.ÿIt's easy! Each volunteer will be allocated a tree or ?stag? to watch for one hour at sunset and will record any animals they observe emerging or entering nest boxes and hollows. This valuable data helps our biodiversity staff to monitor native animal populations, nest box usage and peak activity times in the Sanctuary.ÿ Registrations are essential and numbers are limited. Registrations will open approx 4 weeks prior to the event and will close 12pm on the day before the event.   FAQs Can I get tickets for multiple people? Definitely! However, as we need names of each person attending the event, we do require each person to register separately. Do I need any specialised knowledge or skills? No! While we love to have volunteers who have a background knowledge of our local flora and fauna, it is not essential. Each citizen science event starts with a briefing to let you know what you will be doing. ÿCan children attend this event? There is no minimum age requirement to take part in this citizen science event, but please be mindful that our volunteers are generally required to either sit either record calls or observe wildlife. So, providing children can sit quietly in the dark for an expended period of time with out getting bored, they are welcome to attend. Childrenÿmust be accompanied by an adult at all times.ÿ Why do you need name and mobile number for each person? You will be heading into the Sanctuary after dark, so as a safety precaution we accurate details (name and contact number) for each person attending the event. The mobile number is so that we can contact you in the event of an emergency.ÿ I can't stay until the end of the event, am I able to leave early? Due to the way we run these events, we need you to be able to stay until the scheduled finish time. If you were to leave early then you may not be able to do the survey for the allocated time or you may interupt other groups who are recording at a different site. ÿHow can I contact the organiser with any questions? If you have any questions, please contact us on (03) 9479 1206 or wildlife@latrobe.edu.au
summary: La Trobe Wildlife Sanctuary - Citizen Science Event Come and help monitor arboreal mammals, birds and bats that utilise the nest boxes and n

name__text: LGBTI Ageing & Aged Care Training - Parkdale
description__text: Have you considered the older people you engage with may belong to the LGBTI community? Is your organisation prepared to meet the new Aged Care Quality Standards? Are you aware of the Aged Care Dviersity Framework LGBTI Action Plan? We are offering training which will help you develop an understanding of the experiences and needs of older LGBTI people and how these aspects influence service knowledge, barriers and access.  The session provides an introduction to LGBTI inclusive practice and frameworks for individual practice and/or service development. You will take part in a mix of presentations of LGBTI-related research, policy, interactive activities, legislation and aged care reforms, case studies, educational videos, and facilitated discussion. Relevant to all staff and volunteers who provide support services to older people in the aged care and community sectors. Download flyer...
summary: Have you considered the older people you engage with may belong to the LGBTI community? Is your organisation prepared to meet the new Aged C

name__text: World Environment Day planting
description__text: At this large planting you can take action to help nature and celebrate World Environment Day. The Mt Ridley Nature Conservation Reserve needs more mid-storey tree and shrub species to create habitat for small woodland birds. Some of these beautiful woodland birds are becoming quite rare to find, yet play a very important role by controlling infestations of sap-sucking lerp insects, which impact on the health of the majestic River Red Gums. Join in with corporate volunteers from the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning (DELWP), National Australia Bank (NAB), and other community members. Pizzas are on offer for lunch, or please bring you own lunch if you have special dietary requirements. FAQs Are there ID or minimum age requirements to enter the event? Hume City Council's Greening events are free family-friendly and child-safe activities, with people of all ages and backgrounds welcomed. Participants up to the ages of 85 are covered by Council's Personal Accident Insurance policy, but participants older than 85 years are NOT covered and participate at their own risk. Children must be supervised by their parent or guardian at all times. Please register your attendance on the event sign-in sheet and follow the event supervisor's safe working instructions.ÿ What are my transport/parking options for getting to and from the event? Car-parking is usually available on the surrounding streets to the planting site, or at designated reserve carparks.ÿ For public transport options, check the PTV Journey Planner atÿhttp://jp.ptv.vic.gov.au/ What can I bring into the event? Please wear old comfortable clothing that you wouldn't mind getting dirty, with safe enclosed shoes. Consider if you need to bring a rain jacket or a sun-smart hat. Bring a drink bottle (water, tea and coffee will be provided) and your own packed lunch if you have any special dietary requirements (a simple BBQ lunch or pizzas are catered for lunch, with fruit snacks). All the other tools, equipment and materials required will be provided by Council, including gloves and sunscreen.ÿ When will events be cancelled? Greening events will be cancelled if there is bad weather forecast, including heavy rain, thunderstorms or gale force winds. However light drizzling rain is great planting weather and the event will go ahead if people arrive (check the rain radar on http://www.bom.gov.au/products/IDR023.loop.shtml#skip). Council staff are normally out on site about an hour before the event commences, setting up.ÿ How can I contact the organiser with any questions? Contact Melissa Doherty, Urban Biodiversity Officer at Hume City Council 9205 24660409 702 086melissado@hume.vic.gov.au
summary: At this large planting you can take action to help nature and celebrate World Environment Day. The Mt Ridley Nature Conservation Reserve nee

name__text: Womens Wrench Night
description__text: We're kicking off a monthly Womens Wrench Night at Kustom Kommune with the crew from Wrench Wrenches. These nights are open to everyone and you do not need to be a member to participate. Each month will have a focus on different aspects of your motorcycle. You'll be able to learn all the basics to keep your motorcycle in a safe and well maintained condition. If you find an issue, we can help you source parts and then to fit them up at the following Wrench Night. September: Basic Service - Oil Change, Air Filter and Spark plugsOctober:ÿDrive line - Chain & Sprocket + TyresNovember:ÿBrakes - Pads, Discs & FluidsDecember: Suspension - Fluid and WearJanuary: OFFÿFebruary: Custom night! Make some Mods. While the workshop is open to everyone on a Tuesday evening, we'll have specific volunteers on, along with Giang from Wrench Wenches, to help those attending the Womens Wrench Night. If you've never worked on your moto before, or imporiving exisiting skills, these are the perfect nights to learn all the basics, from intorduction to hand tools, through to working on your bike. These open nights are completely free of charge and we really encourage people to swing past and check out the nights even if you're not working on a bike. Kustom Kommune prides itself on being a space for everyone so get involved and learn some new skills!
summary: We're kicking off a monthly Womens Wrench Night at Kustom Kommune with the crew from Wrench Wrenches. These nights are open to everyone and

name__text: Free | Yoga with milk tea #PlanOfTheMonth
description__text: Every Sunday afternoon. For more information, you may chatÿhereÿon Facebook, or add @LiveADeliciousLifeÿto join Foodie WeChat group.      Too busy to do anything?Yeah there are apps teaching you everythingBut they can waitBut you don?t have to Why not start by doing the bare minimum? Come spend 1h of your life with strangers, for 20mins of yoga for beginners20mins of milk tea making and drinking20mins of #PlanOfTheMonth sharingOkay?------------------------------#PlanOfTheMonthWhat's going on in your head lately?From secret projects you've been working onTo art museums you are gonna visit this monthPlease feel free to talk about anything------------------------------WHERE AND HOWTo make the event happen, it requires at least1 host(who says hi to everyone, offers venues, sets the amount of money to share the cost of ingredients, and collects payments)1 coach(who teaches yoga poses that suit you)1 creator(who makes milk tea to make your day)?N Guests (Number depends on the venue)Please choose your role when signing up. You can be the host, coach and creator at the same time if you are just that awesome.------------------------------Free For everyoneAll guests pay only for ingredients (It's free should you BYO ingredients)Host serves you for freeCoach / Creator teaches for freeFun times for EVERYBODY------------------------------Sign up nowEveryone is a volunteer, here to host, teach or learn.Events will be canceled automatically if no hosts / coaches / chefs / guests sign up.------------------------------To attend / create more events, go toFoodie WeChat group Add @LiveADeliciousLifeFoodie Facebook page @LiveADeliciousLife.globe------------------------------Have a delicious time at a surprisingly low price!FoodieTo have a new place you call home wherever you goInvite yourself to delicious events in the neighborhoods around the globe
summary: Every Sunday afternoon. For more information, you may chatÿhereÿon Facebook, or add @LiveADeliciousLifeÿto join Foodie WeChat group.

name__text: Introduction to Wildlife Photography
description__text: Learn how to avoid some of the common mistakes when taking photos of our native wildlife and natural environment from keen nature photographer and Council?s Environment & Education Team Leader Ian Moodie. Ian will share some of his experiences from taking photos of the natural world for more than 50 years, including advice on the best places to photograph native fauna and flora in our local area.  Following the talk, join Ian and local volunteers on a guided tour of the Sanctuary and put your learning into action. This event is part of Whitehorse Sustainable Living Week, see the full program of fantastic free events here.
summary: Learn how to avoid some of the common mistakes when taking photos of our native wildlife and natural environment from keen nature photograph

description__text: Come and hear engaging speakers from VALiD: ÿPeer Action Group Facilitators and Community Development workers talk about creating community. ÿ This session will cover: ÿ  Everyday challenges facing people with a disability   ÿ  The role that self advocacy plays in helping people with disabilities to identify what?s important to them   ÿ  Learn about how your neighbourhood house can get involved with VALiDs peer action group network  ÿ  The power of partnerships and collaboration with people with disabilities to create change in your local community. name__text: CoderDojo at Balwyn Library
description__text: CoderDojo is a club for young people aged 7 to 17 where they can learn coding withÿhelp from volunteers. If you?re interested in learning code, developing websites, apps, programs, games or exploring technology in an informal, safe, and creative environment, this club is for you! The club will meet on the fourth Sunday of the month (except during school holidays) from 1pm to 2.30pm, on the following dates:ÿ26 May, 23 June, 28 July, 25 August, 27 October, 24 November. BYO laptop or other device.ÿ All attendees need to bring a current Boroondara Library membership card to access the wifi network. For more information on joining the library visit:ÿhttps://www.boroondara.vic.gov.au/libraries/join-library Registrations for each month will open at 3pm after the end of the previous month's session. A parent or adult guardian must attend along with a participating child.
summary: CoderDojo is a club for young people aged 7 to 17 where they can learn coding withÿhelp from volunteers. If you?re interested in learning co

name__text: Darebin Repair Cafe #7 Our first birthday!
description__text: Darebin Repair cafe #7 will be at 220 High St Preston. Our 7th Repair cafe is our first birthday and we are back where we kicked off in May 2018 at The Bridge, Preston.ÿ Bring your item requiring repair to the Darebin Repair Cafe and our community of fixers will repair it. You sit with your personal 'fixer' and explain what is wrong with your item so you can learn how to repair it again in the future. The Moon Rabbit Cafe will be open on the day for your snack and coffee needs for purchasing.  Repair Cafes are a worldwide movement to challenge designÿobsolescenceÿand share fixing skills within our community. Fixing, instead of throwing out and purchasing another item saves resources and keeps skills in our community alive.Repairs on: bicycles, jewellery, shoes,general, glueing, darning, clothes, small machines, toys.  What to do - 1. Book a time slot here on eventbrite. 2. Email us with information on the item including photo and manual if available to ÿtransitiondarebin@gmail.com. 3. Turn up on the day. (come early, so there is time to look over your item)  Note - we may not always be able to repair an item - but best efforts will be made. If you know what parts are needed - please provide them on the day.  Pre-booking is essential as places are limited. People living in the council area of Darebin will be given first priority for tickets.   For more information on the session or if you can provide volunteer assistance on the day - Contact Transitiondarebin@gmail.com  We are kindly supported by the City of Darebin.  For more information on Repair Cafes and the International Repair Cafe Foundation that we are affiliated with - seeÿhttps://repaircafe.org/en/  Repair Cafes are a great way to connect with others in your community and build your skills. We are keen to hear If you would like to register as a fixer or provide some assistance with the many and varied jobs on the day likeÿsetting up, packing up, ushering, tea/coffee, baking, administrative tasks such as registration, weighing, photography, handing out and collection of waiver forms etc.ÿ  Note - by purchasing a ticket, you are agreeing to be added to Transition Darebin's mailing list where we will send you occasional emails on upcoming events and items of interest happening within the council area of Darebin and surrounds.
summary: Darebin Repair cafe #7 will be at 220 High St Preston. Our 7th Repair cafe is our first birthday and we are back where we kicked off in Ma

name__text: Climbers
description__text: CLIMBERS Written by Elly D'Arcy Directed by Elly D'Arcy and Natalie Speechley  May 16 ? 25, 7:30pm in The MUST Space, no show on Sun 19 and Wed 22 Earlier show 6:30pm Mon 20 Post-show Q&A on Tue 21 Matinee 2pm Sat 25 Running time: 2 hours CW: violence and sexual assault Illustration by Hannah Aroni Tickets MSA Rewards $15 | Concession $17 | Full $21 (Please note - we do not offer refunds or exchanges for tickets)    It?s midnight in Newnham College, Cambridge, 1939. Rosalind wants adventure, Lucy wants romance, Ruth wants a Marxist utopia, Tommy wants toÿbe a tortured artist, Dilys wants order (and young men with beautiful brown eyes) and Jane justÿwants to be left alone.ÿThe arrival of three night-climbing students from the men?s colleges changes their lives inÿunexpected ways.ÿBut this newfound ?Jolly Good Fun? comes with a darker side. Climbers is what happens when you take the plucky boarding school heroine out of the boardingÿschool to face the harsh realities of women?s lives on the brink of war.    FAQs What are my transport/parking options for getting to and from the event? Parking at Monash University Clayton comes at no charge in the evenings. The closest car park is near Robert Blackwood Hall, off Wellington Road. We will have signs directing you where to go, so you don't get lost! The bus loop has the 601 bus that travels directly to and from Huntingdale Station. Or, just search Monash Uni Student Theatre on Google Maps!ÿ What's the refund policy? We do not offer refunds or exchanges for tickets. Please double check your availability before purchasing a ticket! Do I have to bring my printed ticket to the event? No you don't! Our friendly Front of House volunteers will tick off your name at the door. Please note: if you purchase an MSA Rewards ticket, we will ask to see your MSA Rewards card.
summary: CLIMBERS Written by Elly D'Arcy Directed by Elly D'Arcy and Natalie Speechley  May 16 ? 25, 7:30pm in The MUST Space, no show on Sun 19 and

name__text: Time and Tide - The presence of J.B.O Hosking: A photographic exhibition
description__text: More than 1600 negatives collected by J.B.O Hosking, Melbourne Harbour Trust Chief Engineer from 1936 to 1959, have been painstakingly indexed and digitised by Public Record Office Victoria volunteers.ÿ The black and white images depict Port of Melbourne facilities and activities including many of those overseen by Mr Hosking himself such as the development of Appleton Dock, operation of the Yarraville fuel terminals and the evolution of the Williamstown and Port Melbourne wharfs in a changing landscape.ÿ Five volunteers spent more than three years bringing the records of the Melbourne Harbour Trust (including the images of J.B.O. Hosking) to life, with two volunteers and a committee of staff curating their favourites for this photographic exhibition. And if you look closely throughout, you may spot Mr Hosking himself appear throughout these stunning still scenes.ÿ Celebrate the launch of this volunteer-led exhibition with us thisÿNational Volunteers Week - "Making a world of difference." ÿ A PUBLIC RECORD OFFICE VICTORIA VOLUNTEER SHOWCASELAUNCH: 2-4PM SATURDAY 25 MAY 2019    The exhibition will remain on display until September.ÿ You will be able to download photographs from the Melbourne Harbour Trust collection, including those on display, from prov.vic.gov.au later in the year.  Pictured from the collection: Undated and undescribed photograph from the Black and White negatives of the Melbourne Harbour Trust Commissioners, VPRS 8359 P1 Unit 1 Item 5A/002 ÿ We have more than 175 volunteers at PROV who spend time digitising and indexing our collection, making it more accessible to the public. Learn more about our volunteer program here:ÿhttps://prov.vic.gov.au/about-us/i-want-volunteer
summary: More than 1600 negatives collected by J.B.O Hosking, Melbourne Harbour Trust Chief Engineer from 1936 to 1959, have been painstakingly index

name__text: Workshop Windbreak
description__text: Toot times three! Come help the volunteers at Bulla Hill Miniature Railway as we continue to try establishing a windbreak around the back of the workshop area. Enter workshop driveway just after CFA. A free BBQ provided for lunch. FAQs  Are there ID or minimum age requirements to enter the event? Hume City Council's Greening events are free family-friendly and child-safe activities, with people of all ages and backgrounds welcomed. Participants up to the ages of 85 are covered by Council's Personal Accident Insurance policy, but participants older than 85 years are NOT covered and participate at their own risk. Children must be supervised by their parent or guardian at all times. Please register your attendance on the event sign-in sheet, and follow the event supervisor's safe working instructions.ÿ What are my transport/parking options for getting to and from the event? Car-parking is usually available on the surrounding streets to the planting site, or at designated reserve carparks.ÿ For public transport options, check the PTV Journey Planner atÿhttp://jp.ptv.vic.gov.au/ What can I bring into the event? Please wear old comfortable clothing that you wouldn't mind getting dirty, with safe enclosed shoes. Consider if you need to bring a rain jacket or a sun-smart hat. Bring a drink bottle (water, tea and coffee will be provided) and your own packed lunch if you have any special dietary requirements (a simple BBQ lunch or pizzas are catered for lunch, with fruit snacks). All of the other tools, equipment and materials required will be provided by Council, including gloves and sunscreen.ÿ When will events be cancelled? Greening events will cancelled if there is bad weather forecast, including heavy rain, thunderstorms or gale force winds. However light drizzling rain is great planting weather and the event will go ahead if people arrive (check the rain radar on http://www.bom.gov.au/products/IDR023.loop.shtml#skip). Council staff are normally out on site about an hour before the event commences, setting up.ÿ How can I contact the organiser with any questions? Contact Melissa Doherty, Urban Biodiversity Officer at Hume City Council 9205 2466 0409 702 086 melissado@hume.vic.gov.au
summary: Toot times three! Come help the volunteers at Bulla Hill Miniature Railway as we continue to try establishing a windbreak around the back of

name__text: #MelbWriteUp ? May 2019
description__text: # Please register separately for each day you plan to attend # #MelbWriteUpÿis a weekly, intensive, socially supportive writing day that uses the pomodoro method. Researchers at all levels of experience and from many institutions are using #MelbWriteUpÿto work on book chapters, journal articles, conference presentations and doctoral theses. While writing is the main focus of our activity, researchers are also using the event to perform any research related activity, such as coding, transcription and data analysis. The day gives you the opportunity to dedicate intense, distraction free focus to your research - and to meet other researchers during the breaks. You can read moreÿaboutÿ#MelbWriteUpÿon a recent blogpost by Julia Dehm.ÿ Ticket caps As space is limited, tickets will be capped for this event. Please consider your availability carefully before booking a ticket as not turning up will mean another person will miss out.ÿ Schedule   10.10 - 10.35 Pomo #1 (Chair #1)   10.40 - 11.05 Pomo #2   11.05 - 11.20ÿMorning tea   11.20 - 11.45 Pomo #3 (Chair #2)   11.50 - 12.15 Pomo #4   12.20 - 12.45 Pomo #5   12.45 - 2.00ÿLunch   2.00 - 2.25 Pomo #6 (Chair #3)   2.30 - 2.55 Pomo #7   3.00 - 3.25 Pomo #8   3.25 - 3.45ÿAfternoon tea   3.45 - 4.10 Pomo #9 (Chair #4)   4.15 - 4.40 Pomo #10   4.40 -ÿWrap upÿ   A full day of research As #MelbWriteUpÿis all about maximising a full day of research, all participants are strongly encouraged to stay for the whole event ? start to finish. It's recommended that you make preparations in advance that can sustain your output for the whole day. While it can be challenging to write for a whole day ? it's also equally rewarding when we all get to the end!ÿ Chairs of each session Three volunteers required to chair one of the sessions each, between morning tea and lunch, lunch and afternoon tea, and afternoon tea and wrap up. Chairing will involve timing the pomodoro and making sure the segments run to schedule.ÿÿ Coffee, tea and water Fresh coffee and tea are available close by at cafes on Swanston Street. Water is available within the building and via vending machines. Power and WiFi Power points are available at the venue. Free WiFi is available from the EDUROAM network. If you have an affiliation with any university on this network, you should be able to access it. It's recommended that you check with your local IT support before attending the event, to make sure your settings are configured correctly. Catering Catering will not be provided on the day. It's requested that we each contribute one item towards morning tea and afternoon tea. Participants are invited to bring their own lunch on the day, or avail of local dining options in the Swanston Street area.ÿ Personal belongings Please keep your personal belongings with you when leaving the venue. At times, particularly during the breaks, the room may be left unoccupied. As it is not possible to lock the room during the day, it is safest to bring your valuables with you if you're popping out.ÿ Access on the day If you have any issues accessing the building or room on the day, feel free to call: 0435 659 297.ÿ Cancellation Demand for the sessions is high. If you can no longer make it, please contact Jason in advance so he can arrange to pass your place on to the next person on the waiting list. Registrations for future events Registrations will be for each individual event. An email will be sent to all participants and those who have expressed an interest in attending. Places will be filled on a first come, first served basis.ÿ Dates for 2019 #MelbWriteUp will run every Saturday during 2019, commencing 5 January.ÿ Keep in touch If you would like to subscribe for email updates about #MelbWriteUp, sign up to the email distribution list. You can also follow Jason on Twitter, or watch the #MelbWriteUp hashtag to keep in the loop. Photo provided byÿUnsplash
summary: # Please register separately for each day you plan to attend # #MelbWriteUpÿis a weekly, intensive, socially supportive writing day that use

name__text: The Skills Exchange: Melbourne May 2019
description__text: The Skills Exchange is a place for charities and skilled specialists to come together to solve problems, increase charity capability around the use of technology, and increase the awareness of skilled specialists about the challenges charities face in their daily operations. Skills Exchange events involve charities pitching a communications technology problem to a room of skilled specialists, who are then matched with charities to help resolve the problem. This is a unique opportunity for charities to get access to skilled volunteers from the ICT industry, who have agreed to donate up to two days of their time to give back. Participating charities are supported throughout the entire process from Telco Together, starting with assistance defining and pitching their problem, through to post-event support to ensure all parties maximise the potential for problems to be resolved. Thank you to Cisco for kindly donating the use of the venue for this event.
summary: The Skills Exchange is a place for charities and skilled specialists to come together to solve problems, increase charity capability around

name__text: Volunteer Manager Workshop: Legal Issues in Managing Volunteers
description__text: Volunteer Manager Workshop: Legal Issues in Managing Volunteers  ÿ  Navigating how the law applies to volunteers can be complex and confusing. As volunteers play a critical function in the delivery of support for community organisations, ensuring that your volunteer program is legally compliant is essential.  ÿ  Whether your volunteer program is new or established, do you know how legally compliant your organisation is in managing volunteers?  ÿ  This workshop, delivered by Justice Connect, provides participants with the knowledge required to manage and operate a compliant volunteer program.  ÿ  If your organisation engages volunteers- this workshop is for you!  ÿ  What will I learn?  ÿ  ÿDuring this three hour workshop, you will gain an understanding of:    ÿthe legal differences between a volunteer, an employee and an independent contractor  different forms of unpaid work (including vocational placements, internships, work trials, work for the dole, and court ordered 'volunteering')  volunteers and risk management  volunteer selection process and equal opportunity laws  volunteer screening and background checks  how to meet the ?duty of care? your organisation owes to volunteers  an organisation?s legal responsibility for the actions of its volunteers  the importance of volunteer insurance  workplace behaviours and volunteers (discrimination, sexual harassment, bullying and victimisation)  reimbursing or paying volunteers  volunteers records, personal information and privacy  reviewing volunteer performance and having difficult conversations  ending the volunteer relationship  top tips for managing an effective and legally-compliant volunteer program.    ÿ  ÿ  Details:  Time: 8:30am to 12pm  Date: Thursday 23 May 2019  Location: The Wattle Room, City of Boroondara offices, 8 Inglesby Road Camberwell  Facilitator: Joanna Barnett, Justice Connect  Audience: Volunteer Managers  Cost: Free  Morning tea will be provided.  ÿ  Missed out on tickets? Join our waiting list by emailing: bvrc@boroondara.vic.gov.au
summary: Volunteer Manager Workshop: Legal Issues in Managing Volunteers  ÿ  Navigating how the law applies to volunteers can be complex and confusin

name__text: Community Visitors Scheme  - Volunteer Information Session - Manningham
description__text: Attend a Free Information session and find out more about becoming a volunteer in Doncare?s Community Visitors Scheme Are you interested in providingÿfriendship and companionship toÿolder members of the local community?ÿ ÿ Doncare's Community Visitors Scheme (CVS) is a national program funded by the Australian government and plays a vital role in providing companionship for older people who are experiencing loneliness or isolation living in Residential Aged Care Homes or living in their own homes and receiving a Commonwealth Aged Care Package.ÿ Doncare is recruiting volunteers who enjoy the company of older people and areÿcommitted to building and sustaining a friendship through weekly visits over the course of a 12 month period.ÿ An information session will be held on 22 May, 2019 for people interested in volunteering as a Community Visitor. Topics covered will include:  What is the Community Visitors Scheme? What does a community visitor do?ÿ Who can become a Volunteer Community Visitor?ÿ How will Doncare support me as a volunteer?   The Community Visitors Scheme (CVS) activity received grant funding from the Australian Government.

name__text: (Melbourne) Volunteer Induction Night - Meditation with Baby Goats
description__text: Are you fun, fur-loving and looking for deeper meaning in this crazy adventure called Life?      We?re now recruiting Karma Krew volunteers for 2019 for our Melbourne series of Breathe In & Bleat Out - Melbourne! Please note this is an online event :P       How does it benefit you?    Making new connections or friendships   Self-care   Animal-assisted therapy during event break   Opportunities to facilitate fundraising events, including Aunties & Uncles (Foster-care), Beyond Blue & Black Dog Institute (Mental Health)   Work experience managing events, administration/marketing and photography/videography.    Discounts      How does it benefit us?    We exist to bring the best out of every human we meet. We raise individuals to their highest potential to close the gap between animals and humans, fostering a kinder, more connected world. With your help, we're spreading our message far and wide, alleviating mental health, and improving relationships between humans and furry friends across Australia.      You may be asked to:       Set up studio equipment   Pack down studio equipment   Greet guests   Take photos or videos   Clean up after animals   Carry animals      Our messages   ? We believe human potential is infinite   ? We know all beings deserve compassion   ? We assume the best in others   ? We value mental health & social contribution   ? We provide funding for charitable organisations   ? We regard mistakes and failures as our greatest teachers      Please read carefully:    Please only book in if you're serious about volunteering. Unless you have booked your free spot via Eventbrite & Emailed YES to Re-confirm, you have not reserved your space.       How do I join the meeting?   Just follow these instructions below. You will also be emailed the following instructions:    Berenice Tan is inviting you to a scheduled Zoom meeting.   Topic: Karmably Volunteer Meeting   Time: May 20, 2019 8:00 PM Brisbane   Join Zoom Meeting   https://us04web.zoom.us/j/288041850      We can?t wait to bleat you!   The Karma Krew   Email. berenice@karmably.com.au   Phone. 0430 020 280
summary: Are you fun, fur-loving and looking for deeper meaning in this crazy adventure called Life?      We?re now recruiting Karma Krew volunteers

name__text: International Museum Day Malcolm Fraser Book Collection and Archives tour
description__text: Malcolm Fraser Book Collection and Archives The Malcolm Fraser Collection at the University of Melbourne currently consists of one hundred metres of family and personal records relating to the former Prime Minister of Australia, the Rt. Hon. Malcolm Fraser and his personal library. This tour will focus on the books from the personal library and what private book collections can reveal about their owner. The tour will be led by Carole Hinchcliff, Law School Librarian on Secondment to the Threads of the Past Project and Roxane Le Guen, Cultural Collections Volunteer ÿFor more information on the Malcolm Fraser Collection visit https://archives.unimelb.edu.au/explore/collections/malcolmfraser
summary: Malcolm Fraser Book Collection and Archives The Malcolm Fraser Collection at the University of Melbourne currently consists of one hundred m

name__text: Gambling, Sports Betting and Young People
description__text: A free forum for professionals and community leaders that work with young people ÿOnline gambling and sports betting is increasingly part of everyday life. Gambling advertising is changing the way young people see sport. Smartphones and tablets provide easy access for young people to gambling at any time, even if they are under age. This normalisation means that young people are less likely to recognise the dangers associated with gambling and further increase their risks.ÿÿ At this free forum, you will hear from:  Associate Professor Samantha Thomas fromÿDeakin Universityÿabout the latest research on the impact of gambling advertising on children and young people AÿRe-SPINÿCommunity Educator about their experience of gambling harm Gamblers Help Easternÿ about practical information and help services available  This forum is designed for professionals and community leaders that work with young people under the age of 25. This includes:  Youth workersÿÿ Teachersÿ ÿ ÿ ÿ ÿÿ Health and community workers University/TAFE professionals Community leaders and volunteers Sportsclubs Youth and peer leaders  ÿMorning tea provided This is a free event but registration is required Please note any special dietary requirements when registering your place   FAQs ÿ What are my transport/parking options for getting to and from the event? Camberwell Civic Centre is located on the 75 Tram route and is a short walk from Camberwell Railway Station. Plan your Journey with PTVÿ There are a number of parking options in the Camberwell Civic Precinct. For more information visit: https://www.boroondara.vic.gov.au/parking-roads/transport/find-car-park How can I contact the organiser with any questions? For more information contact the City of Boroondara? s Community Planning and Development department on 9278 4715
summary: A free forum for professionals and community leaders that work with young people ÿOnline gambling and sports betting is increasingly part o
